Well, in this case, most of them were probably crazy and some of the EVP
I've gotten indicates they're still crazy. So who knows what they're
thinking?

As far as normal people who end up sticking around as ghosts in cemeteries,
that's an even bigger mystery. I think traumatic experiences, such as being
killed on a battlefield, can make you stick in that area. I was told by a
Scottish friend that there are still ghosts fighting the battle on the
battlefield portrayed in the movie Braveheart. That was over 700 years ago.
No one told them they're dead.

Zack

>  One of the most fascinating ones I ever got was recorded in the ruins
> of a former mental hospital. The building is shaped like an "H" and our
> group of about 10 people was standing in one arm of the "H" looking through
> the windows to the opposite arm. We saw a shadow moving around inside the
> building in the other arm. We were just discussing this when a hoarse voice
> came in THREE times on the recording and said "It's Harold Wing." This voice
> was not audible to our ears at the time of the investigation.
> Later on, one of the members of our group was able to access old records
> for the mental hospital and found there was indeed a patient named Harold
> Wing who died there of typhoid fever in 1936. There is no way any of us
> could've known that at the time and it's doubtful anyone living would've
> known about it at the time, either.
